content: The "Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012" aims to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts. The Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012 seeks to enhance small business involvement in multiple award contracts by mandating the inclusion of small business concerns and maximizing the utilization of set-aside programs. The Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012 aims to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts through an Agency Outreach Program. This program includes increasing awareness, providing education and training, assisting with contract listings, and tracking small business participation. The Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012 aims to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts. The Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012 aims to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts by defining key terms. The Small Business Act is amended to include various types of contracts such as Federal Supply Schedule program contracts, multi-agency contracts, and Government-wide acquisition contracts. Additionally, the term 'blanket Purchase Agreement' is defined in the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to include definitions of 'blanket Purchase Agreement' and 'basic Ordering Agreement' based on specific sections of the Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 4 amends the Small Business Act to establish Government-wide goals for task orders placed against multiple award contracts awarded to various small business concerns. SEC. 5 focuses on improvements to the Small Business Reserve. Section 15(j) of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the monetary threshold from $100,000 to $200,000. Additionally, regulations will be issued within 120 days regarding the correct application of size standards for task orders placed against multiple award contracts. The Small Business Act is amended to increase the monetary threshold to $200,000 and regulations will be issued for the correct application of size standards for task orders. The General Services Administration will ensure implementation of non-manufacturer rule and subcontracting provisions at the task order level, and display correct size information for small businesses on electronic ordering systems. SEC. 6. SMALL BUSINESS REPRESENTATION ON THE FEDERAL ACQUISITION REGULATORY COUNCIL. Amends Section 1302(b)(1) of title 41, United States Code to include the Administrator of the Small Business Administration on the council. Additionally, in case of a tie vote, the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy will have the deciding vote.
